verses.text: Woe is me! For I have become like one gathering summer fruit, like the gleanings after the grape harvest. No cluster to eat—no early figs that my soul desires.
verses.comment: Micah laments the lack of righteous people, symbolized by the absence of fruit after harvest. This is a metaphor for spiritual barrenness in Israel.

verses.text: The godly have vanished from the land, and no upright person remains. Everyone lies in wait for blood; they hunt each other with nets.
verses.comment: Micah describes moral decay, paralleling Psalm 12 and Jeremiah 5. This highlights humanity’s universal need for redemption.

verses.text: Both hands are skilled at evil—the official and the judge ask for a bribe, and the powerful dictate their desires; they weave it together.
verses.comment: Corruption is shown at every level, emphasizing the depth of sin and the need for righteous leadership.

verses.text: The best among them is like a thorn; the most upright is worse than a hedge of thorns. The day of your watchmen, your punishment, has come. Now is their confusion.
verses.comment: Even the ‘best’ people are dangerous and unfruitful. The punishment is imminent, underscoring the holiness of God's justice.

verses.text: Do not trust a neighbor; do not put confidence in a friend. Guard the doors of your mouth from her who lies in your arms.
verses.comment: Micah warns of betrayal even in closest relationships. This points to the brokenness caused by sin and foreshadows Christ’s experience.

verses.text: For the son treats the father with contempt, the daughter rises up against her mother, the daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law; a person’s enemies are the members of his own household.
verses.comment: Jesus quotes this verse, applying it to His own ministry. The division caused by following Him fulfills Micah’s prophecy, revealing the cost of discipleship.

verses.text: But as for me, I will look to the Lord; I will wait for the God of my salvation. My God will hear me.
verses.comment: Micah turns to God with steadfast hope for salvation, foreshadowing the spiritual attitude of trust central to Christian faith.

verses.text: Do not rejoice over me, my enemy. Though I have fallen, I will rise; though I sit in darkness, the Lord will be my light.
verses.comment: The rising from darkness prefigures resurrection themes and Christ as the Light of the world. John 8:12 presents Jesus as this fulfillment.

verses.text: I will endure the anger of the Lord because I have sinned against Him, until He pleads my case and executes justice for me. He will bring me to the light; I will see His righteousness.
verses.comment: Micah accepts God’s discipline but anticipates vindication, echoing themes of intercession and atonement ultimately fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Then my enemy will see, and shame will cover her who said to me, 'Where is the Lord your God?' My eyes will look upon her; now she will be trampled down like mud in the streets.
verses.comment: The vindication of the faithful is promised. This links to themes of suffering for faith and ultimate triumph over evil.

verses.text: A day for building your walls will come; the boundary will be extended in that day.
verses.comment: Promise of restoration and expansion. Scriptural motif of the city’s walls recalls the spiritual building up of the people of God.

verses.text: In that day people will come to you from Assyria and the cities of Egypt, and from Egypt to the Euphrates, from sea to sea and mountain to mountain.
verses.comment: The ingathering of nations is promised—the openness of God’s people to the whole earth prefigures the universal mission of Christ’s Church.

verses.text: Yet the earth will become desolate because of its inhabitants, as a result of their deeds.
verses.comment: Sin brings judgment and desolation on the earth, affirming the seriousness of moral consequences for creation.

verses.text: Shepherd your people with your staff, the flock of your inheritance, dwelling by itself in a forest in fertile land; let them graze in Bashan and Gilead as in days of old.
verses.comment: Micah appeals to God as shepherd, echoing Psalm 80 and Ezekiel 34, prefiguring Christ as the Good Shepherd.

verses.text: As in the days when you came out from the land of Egypt, I will show them marvelous things.
verses.comment: God’s saving acts are recalled, connecting the Exodus to future salvation—miraculous deliverance that foreshadows Christ’s work.

verses.text: The nations will see and be ashamed of all their might; they will put their hand over their mouth; their ears will become deaf.
verses.comment: Universal recognition of God’s power and silence before His majesty, foreshadowing the spread of the Gospel and conversion of the nations.

verses.text: They will lick dust like a serpent; like crawling creatures on the earth, they will come trembling out of their strongholds; they will turn in dread to the Lord our God, and will fear you.
verses.comment: Imagery recalls Genesis 3:14, linking divine judgment and humility, underscoring triumph of God over evil.

verses.text: Who is a God like you, forgiving iniquity and passing over transgression for the remnant of His inheritance? He does not hold on to His anger forever, because He delights in mercy.
verses.comment: The heart of Micah’s prophecy—God’s mercy is limitless. This connects with the central Christian teaching of forgiveness and grace.

verses.text: He will again have compassion on us. He will tread our iniquities underfoot. You will cast all our sins into the depths of the sea.
verses.comment: God’s victory over sin is total: casting sins into the sea prefigures complete forgiveness, foreshadowing Christ’s redemptive work.

verses.text: You will show faithfulness to Jacob, and steadfast love to Abraham, as you swore to our ancestors from days of old.
verses.comment: Micah concludes with God’s covenant fidelity—fulfilled supremely in Christ, and experienced through the community gathered in unity and sacramental life.
